members.documentation: The stack AWS region, such as "us-east-1". For more information about AWS regions, see Regions and Endpoints.

members.name: VpcId
members.documentation: The VPC ID; applicable only if the stack is running in a VPC.

members.name: Attributes
members.documentation: The stack's attributes.

members.name: ServiceRoleArn
members.documentation: The stack AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) role.

members.name: DefaultInstanceProfileArn
members.documentation: The ARN of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

members.name: DefaultOs
members.documentation: The stack's default operating system.

members.name: HostnameTheme
members.documentation: The stack host name theme, with spaces replaced by underscores.

members.name: DefaultAvailabilityZone
members.documentation: The stack's default Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

members.name: DefaultSubnetId
members.documentation: The default subnet ID; applicable only if the stack is running in a VPC.

members.name: CustomJson
members.documentation:
A JSON object that contains user-defined attributes to be added to the stack configuration and deployment attributes. You can use custom JSON to override the corresponding default stack configuration attribute values or to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the following format and must escape characters such as '"':

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

For more information on custom JSON, see Use Custom JSON to Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes.

members.name: ConfigurationManager
members.documentation: The configuration manager.

members.name: ChefConfiguration
members.documentation: A ChefConfiguration object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version. For more information, see Create a New Stack.

members.name: UseCustomCookbooks
members.documentation: Whether the stack uses custom cookbooks.

members.name: UseOpsworksSecurityGroups
members.documentation: Whether the stack automatically associates the AWS OpsWorks built-in security groups with the stack's layers.

members.name: DefaultSshKeyName
members.documentation: A default Amazon EC2 key pair for the stack's instances. You can override this value when you create or update an instance.

members.name: CreatedAt
members.documentation: The date when the stack was created.

members.name: DefaultRootDeviceType
members.documentation: The default root device type. This value is used by default for all instances in the stack, but you can override it when you create an instance. For more information, see Storage for the Root Device.

members.name: AgentVersion
members.documentation: The agent version. This parameter is set to LATEST for auto-update. or a version number for a fixed agent version.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The name. This parameter must be set to "Chef".

members.name: Version
members.documentation: The Chef version. This parameter must be set to 0.9, 11.4, or 11.10. The default value is 11.4.

members.name: StackId
members.documentation: The stack ID.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The stack name.

members.name: Arn
members.documentation: The stack's ARN.

members.name: LayersCount
members.documentation: The number of layers.

members.name: AppsCount
members.documentation: The number of apps.

members.name: InstancesCount
members.documentation: An InstancesCount object with the number of instances in each status.

members.name: InstanceId
members.documentation: The instance ID.

members.name: StackId
members.documentation: The stack ID.

members.name: InstanceId
members.documentation: The instance ID.

members.name: StackId
members.documentation: The stack ID.

members.name: Username
members.documentation: The user name.

members.name: Password
members.documentation: The password.

members.name: ValidForInMinutes
members.documentation: The length of time (in minutes) that the grant is valid. When the grant expires, at the end of this period, the user will no longer be able to use the credentials to log in. If they are logged in at the time, they will be automatically logged out.

members.name: InstanceId
members.documentation: The instance's AWS OpsWorks ID.

members.name: InstanceId
members.documentation: The instance ID.

members.name: AutoScalingSchedule
members.documentation: A WeeklyAutoScalingSchedule object with the instance schedule.

members.name: InstanceId
members.documentation: The instance ID.

members.name: VolumeId
members.documentation: The volume ID.

members.name: AppId
members.documentation: The app ID.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The app name.

members.name: Description
members.documentation: A description of the app.

members.name: DataSources
members.documentation: The app's data sources.

members.name: Type
members.documentation: The app type.

members.name: AppSource
members.documentation: A Source object that specifies the app repository.

members.name: Domains
members.documentation: The app's virtual host settings, with multiple domains separated by commas. For example: 'www.example.com, example.com'

members.name: EnableSsl
members.documentation: Whether SSL is enabled for the app.

members.name: SslConfiguration
members.documentation: An SslConfiguration object with the SSL configuration.

members.name: Attributes
members.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes.

members.name: Environment
members.documentation:
An array of EnvironmentVariable objects that specify environment variables to be associated with the app. After you deploy the app, these variables are defined on the associated app server instances.For more information, see Environment Variables.

There is no specific limit on the number of environment variables. However, the size of the associated data structure - which includes the variables' names, values, and protected flag values - cannot exceed 10 KB (10240 Bytes). This limit should accommodate most if not all use cases. Exceeding it will cause an exception with the message, "Environment: is too large (maximum is 10KB)."

This parameter is supported only by Chef 11.10 stacks. If you have specified one or more environment variables, you cannot modify the stack's Chef version.

members.name: ElasticIp
members.documentation: The address.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The new name.

members.name: InstanceId
members.documentation: The instance ID.

members.name: LayerIds
members.documentation: The instance's layer IDs.

members.name: InstanceType
members.documentation: The instance type, such as t2.micro. For a list of supported instance types, open the stack in the console, choose Instances, and choose + Instance. The Size list contains the currently supported types. For more information, see Instance Families and Types. The parameter values that you use to specify the various types are in the API Name column of the Available Instance Types table.

members.name: AutoScalingType
members.documentation: For load-based or time-based instances, the type. Windows stacks can use only time-based instances.

members.name: Hostname
members.documentation: The instance host name.

members.name: Os
members.documentation:
The instance's operating system, which must be set to one of the following.

  • A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such as Amazon Linux 2015.03, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, or Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.
  • Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2 Base.
  • A custom AMI: Custom.

For more information on the supported operating systems, see AWS OpsWorks Operating Systems.

The default option is the current Amazon Linux version. If you set this parameter to Custom, you must use the AmiId parameter to specify the custom AMI that you want to use. For more information on the supported operating systems, see Operating Systems. For more information on how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see Using Custom AMIs.

You can specify a different Linux operating system for the updated stack, but you cannot change from Linux to Windows or Windows to Linux.

members.name: AmiId
members.documentation:
A custom AMI ID to be used to create the instance. The AMI must be based on one of the supported operating systems. For more information, see Instances

If you specify a custom AMI, you must set Os to Custom.

members.name: SshKeyName
members.documentation: The instance's Amazon EC2 key name.

members.name: Architecture
members.documentation: The instance architecture. Instance types do not necessarily support both architectures. For a list of the architectures that are supported by the different instance types, see Instance Families and Types.

members.name: InstallUpdatesOnBoot
members.documentation:
Whether to install operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value is true. To control when updates are installed, set this value to false. You must then update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the update_dependencies stack command or by manually running yum (Amazon Linux) or apt-get (Ubuntu) on the instances.

We strongly recommend using the default value of true, to ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.

members.name: EbsOptimized
members.documentation: This property cannot be updated.

members.name: AgentVersion
members.documentation:
The default AWS OpsWorks agent version. You have the following options:

  • INHERIT - Use the stack's default agent version setting.
  • version_number - Use the specified agent version. This value overrides the stack's default setting. To update the agent version, you must edit the instance configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks then automatically installs that version on the instance.

The default setting is INHERIT. To specify an agent version, you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers, call DescribeAgentVersions.

members.name: LayerId
members.documentation: The layer ID.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The layer name, which is used by the console.

members.name: Shortname
members.documentation:
For custom layers only, use this parameter to specify the layer's short name, which is used internally by AWS OpsWorksand by Chef. The short name is also used as the name for the directory where your app files are installed. It can have a maximum of 200 characters and must be in the following format: /\A[a-z0-9\-\_\.]+\Z/.

The built-in layers' short names are defined by AWS OpsWorks. For more information, see the Layer Reference

members.name: Attributes
members.documentation: One or more user-defined key/value pairs to be added to the stack attributes.

members.name: CustomInstanceProfileArn
members.documentation: The ARN of an IAM profile to be used for all of the layer's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

members.name: CustomJson
members.documentation: A JSON-formatted string containing custom stack configuration and deployment attributes to be installed on the layer's instances. For more information, see Using Custom JSON.

members.name: CustomSecurityGroupIds
members.documentation: An array containing the layer's custom security group IDs.

members.name: Packages
members.documentation: An array of Package objects that describe the layer's packages.

members.name: VolumeConfigurations
members.documentation: A VolumeConfigurations object that describes the layer's Amazon EBS volumes.

members.name: EnableAutoHealing
members.documentation: Whether to disable auto healing for the layer.

members.name: AutoAssignElasticIps
members.documentation: Whether to automatically assign an Elastic IP address to the layer's instances. For more information, see How to Edit a Layer.

members.name: AutoAssignPublicIps
members.documentation: For stacks that are running in a VPC, whether to automatically assign a public IP address to the layer's instances. For more information, see How to Edit a Layer.

members.name: CustomRecipes
members.documentation: A LayerCustomRecipes object that specifies the layer's custom recipes.

members.name: InstallUpdatesOnBoot
members.documentation:
Whether to install operating system and package updates when the instance boots. The default value is true. To control when updates are installed, set this value to false. You must then update your instances manually by using CreateDeployment to run the update_dependencies stack command or manually running yum (Amazon Linux) or apt-get (Ubuntu) on the instances.

We strongly recommend using the default value of true, to ensure that your instances have the latest security updates.

members.name: UseEbsOptimizedInstances
members.documentation: Whether to use Amazon EBS-optimized instances.

members.name: SshPublicKey
members.documentation: The user's SSH public key.

members.name: RdsDbInstanceArn
members.documentation: The Amazon RDS instance's ARN.

members.name: DbUser
members.documentation: The master user name.

members.name: DbPassword
members.documentation: The database password.

members.name: StackId
members.documentation: The stack ID.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The stack's new name.

members.name: Attributes
members.documentation: One or more user-defined key-value pairs to be added to the stack attributes.

members.name: ServiceRoleArn
members.documentation: Do not use this parameter. You cannot update a stack's service role.

members.name: DefaultInstanceProfileArn
members.documentation: The ARN of an IAM profile that is the default profile for all of the stack's EC2 instances. For more information about IAM ARNs, see Using Identifiers.

members.name: DefaultOs
members.documentation:
The stack's operating system, which must be set to one of the following:

  • A supported Linux operating system: An Amazon Linux version, such as Amazon Linux 2015.03, Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7, Ubuntu 12.04 LTS, or Ubuntu 14.04 LTS.
  • Microsoft Windows Server 2012 R2 Base.
  • A custom AMI: Custom. You specify the custom AMI you want to use when you create instances. For more information on how to use custom AMIs with OpsWorks, see Using Custom AMIs.

The default option is the stack's current operating system. For more information on the supported operating systems, see AWS OpsWorks Operating Systems.

members.name: HostnameTheme
members.documentation:
The stack's new host name theme, with spaces replaced by underscores. The theme is used to generate host names for the stack's instances. By default, HostnameTheme is set to Layer_Dependent, which creates host names by appending integers to the layer's short name. The other themes are:

  • Baked_Goods
  • Clouds
  • Europe_Cities
  • Fruits
  • Greek_Deities
  • Legendary_creatures_from_Japan
  • Planets_and_Moons
  • Roman_Deities
  • Scottish_Islands
  • US_Cities
  • Wild_Cats

To obtain a generated host name, call GetHostNameSuggestion, which returns a host name based on the current theme.

members.name: DefaultAvailabilityZone
members.documentation: The stack's default Availability Zone, which must be in the stack's region. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints. If you also specify a value for DefaultSubnetId, the subnet must be in the same zone. For more information, see CreateStack.

members.name: DefaultSubnetId
members.documentation: The stack's default VPC subnet ID. This parameter is required if you specify a value for the VpcId parameter. All instances are launched into this subnet unless you specify otherwise when you create the instance. If you also specify a value for DefaultAvailabilityZone, the subnet must be in that zone. For information on default values and when this parameter is required, see the VpcId parameter description.

members.name: CustomJson
members.documentation:
A string that contains user-defined, custom JSON. It can be used to override the corresponding default stack configuration JSON values or to pass data to recipes. The string should be in the following format and escape characters such as '"':

"{\"key1\": \"value1\", \"key2\": \"value2\",...}"

For more information on custom JSON, see Use Custom JSON to Modify the Stack Configuration Attributes.

members.name: ConfigurationManager
members.documentation: The configuration manager. When you clone a stack, we recommend that you use the configuration manager to specify the Chef version: 0.9, 11.4, or 11.10. The default value is currently 11.4.

members.name: ChefConfiguration
members.documentation: A ChefConfiguration object that specifies whether to enable Berkshelf and the Berkshelf version on Chef 11.10 stacks. For more information, see Create a New Stack.

members.name: UseCustomCookbooks
members.documentation: Whether the stack uses custom cookbooks.

members.name: DefaultSshKeyName
members.documentation: A default Amazon EC2 key-pair name. The default value is none. If you specify a key-pair name, AWS OpsWorks installs the public key on the instance and you can use the private key with an SSH client to log in to the instance. For more information, see Using SSH to Communicate with an Instance and Managing SSH Access. You can override this setting by specifying a different key pair, or no key pair, when you create an instance.

members.name: DefaultRootDeviceType
members.documentation: The default root device type. This value is used by default for all instances in the stack, but you can override it when you create an instance. For more information, see Storage for the Root Device.

members.name: UseOpsworksSecurityGroups
members.documentation:
Whether to associate the AWS OpsWorks built-in security groups with the stack's layers.

AWS OpsWorks provides a standard set of built-in security groups, one for each layer, which are associated with layers by default. UseOpsworksSecurityGroups allows you to provide your own custom security groups instead of using the built-in groups. UseOpsworksSecurityGroups has the following settings:

  • True - AWS OpsWorks automatically associates the appropriate built-in security group with each layer (default setting). You can associate additional security groups with a layer after you create it, but you cannot delete the built-in security group.
  • False - AWS OpsWorks does not associate built-in security groups with layers. You must create appropriate EC2 security groups and associate a security group with each layer that you create. However, you can still manually associate a built-in security group with a layer on. Custom security groups are required only for those layers that need custom settings.

For more information, see Create a New Stack.

members.name: AgentVersion
members.documentation:
The default AWS OpsWorks agent version. You have the following options:

  • Auto-update - Set this parameter to LATEST. AWS OpsWorks automatically installs new agent versions on the stack's instances as soon as they are available.
  • Fixed version - Set this parameter to your preferred agent version. To update the agent version, you must edit the stack configuration and specify a new version. AWS OpsWorks then automatically installs that version on the stack's instances.

The default setting is LATEST. To specify an agent version, you must use the complete version number, not the abbreviated number shown on the console. For a list of available agent version numbers, call DescribeAgentVersions.

You can also specify an agent version when you create or update an instance, which overrides the stack's default setting.

members.name: IamUserArn
members.documentation: The user IAM ARN.

members.name: SshUsername
members.documentation: The user's SSH user name. The allowable characters are [a-z], [A-Z], [0-9], '-', and '_'. If the specified name includes other punctuation marks, AWS OpsWorks removes them. For example, my.name will be changed to myname. If you do not specify an SSH user name, AWS OpsWorks generates one from the IAM user name.

members.name: SshPublicKey
members.documentation: The user's new SSH public key.

members.name: AllowSelfManagement
members.documentation: Whether users can specify their own SSH public key through the My Settings page. For more information, see Managing User Permissions.

members.name: VolumeId
members.documentation: The volume ID.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The new name.

members.name: MountPoint
members.documentation: The new mount point.

members.name: IamUserArn
members.documentation: The user's IAM ARN.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The user's name.

members.name: SshUsername
members.documentation: The user's SSH user name.

members.name: SshPublicKey
members.documentation: The user's SSH public key.

members.name: AllowSelfManagement
members.documentation: Whether users can specify their own SSH public key through the My Settings page. For more information, see Managing User Permissions.

members.name: message
members.documentation: The exception message.

members.name: VolumeId
members.documentation: The volume ID.

members.name: Ec2VolumeId
members.documentation: The Amazon EC2 volume ID.

members.name: Name
members.documentation: The volume name.

members.name: RaidArrayId
members.documentation: The RAID array ID.

members.name: InstanceId
members.documentation: The instance ID.

members.name: Status
members.documentation: The value returned by DescribeVolumes.

members.name: Size
members.documentation: The volume size.

members.name: Device
members.documentation: The device name.

members.name: MountPoint
members.documentation: The volume mount point. For example "/dev/sdh".

members.name: Region
members.documentation: The AWS region. For more information about AWS regions, see Regions and Endpoints.

members.name: AvailabilityZone
members.documentation: The volume Availability Zone. For more information, see Regions and Endpoints.

members.name: VolumeType
members.documentation: The volume type, standard or PIOPS.

members.name: Iops
members.documentation: For PIOPS volumes, the IOPS per disk.

members.name: MountPoint
members.documentation: The volume mount point. For example "/dev/sdh".

members.name: RaidLevel
members.documentation: The volume RAID level.

members.name: NumberOfDisks
members.documentation: The number of disks in the volume.

members.name: Size
members.documentation: The volume size.

members.name: VolumeType
members.documentation:
The volume type:

  • standard - Magnetic
  • io1 - Provisioned IOPS (SSD)
  • gp2 - General Purpose (SSD)

members.name: Iops
members.documentation: For PIOPS volumes, the IOPS per disk.

members.name: Monday
members.documentation: The schedule for Monday.

members.name: Tuesday
members.documentation: The schedule for Tuesday.

members.name: Wednesday
members.documentation: The schedule for Wednesday.

members.name: Thursday
members.documentation: The schedule for Thursday.

members.name: Friday
members.documentation: The schedule for Friday.

members.name: Saturday
members.documentation: The schedule for Saturday.

members.name: Sunday
members.documentation: The schedule for Sunday.
